Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Enabling Analysis and Design of Complex Biological Systems through Data Science
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to Tufts University, located in Medford, MA, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2017- 2019. This project is supported by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (DBI) in the Directorate for Biological Sciences (BIO), the Division of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure (ACI) in the Directorate of Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE), and the Division of Engineering Education and Centers (EEC) in the Directorate for Engineering (ENG). This REU Site will develop data science approaches to analyze and design complex biological systems. Because of the interdisciplinary nature of the program, faculty mentors are drawn from multiple departments across life sciences, engineering, and computing sciences, including Chemical and Biological Engineering, Microbiology, Electrical and Computer engineering, and Computer Science. Research projects deal with the collection, analysis, and modeling of biological data sets to understand or design a system of interest, ranging from microbial communities to bioreactors. The research activities are supported through workshops providing a hands-on introduction to modern data analysis, modeling, and visualization tools. Students will be provided training in responsible conduct of research and ethics through seminars and group discussions led by faculty mentors. Participants will be recruited nationally among rising juniors and seniors majoring in an engineering or life science discipline. Applicants will be selected by a faculty committee of the PI and Co-PI, workshop leaders, and mentors.

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. The students will learn about different STEM learning styles of K-12 students, and be presented opportunities to engage in K-12 outreach.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences) will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://engineering.tufts.edu/research/reu.htm, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Kyongbum Lee at kyongbum.lee@tufts.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Daniel Ryder at daniel.ryder@tufts.edu)

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goals of this REU Site Program were to provide an immersive research experience for undergraduate students in fields at the intersection of biology, engineering, and data science, while connecting the program participants to professional development opportunities. These goals were successfully met.

 

Each REU participant was matched with a research project and sponsoring faculty mentor(s) based on the participant?s research interest. The research projects featured complexity as a theme, and were organized into three clusters: biomolecular engineering, host-microbe interactions, and computational modeling. In addition to the research projects, students in the REU program participated in faculty-led, hands-on workshops introducing techniques for data analysis, modeling, and visualization. The workshops provided an overview of representative computational and statistical approaches for analyzing large, complex data sets that are commonly collected over the course of a systems biology experiment. Further, the workshops introduced the students to an important modality of continuing education that are used by working professionals. The workshops also facilitated community building among the students by having them participate in a common activity alongside their independent research projects. Professional development activities included industry site visits, panel discussions with faculty and industry speakers. Leveraging the expertise of Tufts? Center for Engineering Education and Outreach, the REU program introduced the participants to basic STEM learning concepts. Through a series of workshops, the participants also learned how to design STEM outreach activities that target K-12 students.

 

Over 3 years, the program supported 28 students from diverse backgrounds. More than 70% were female students (compared to a national average of 20% female students in engineering), and 35% were from colleges that do not grant doctoral degrees. All of the students who have graduate their undergraduate programs are pursuing a STEM career by attending graduate school or working at a government/industry laboratory.  

 

The REU program?s effectiveness was assessed through NSF BIO designed survey instruments. The survey results reported across the board strong personal gains. Notably, the participants reported gains in not only research skills and confidence, but also appreciation for collaborative work and interest in pursuing a career in science.  

 

Key scientific findings from the REU participants? projects have been published in five peer-reviewed journal articles. The findings have also been broadly disseminated to the public through presentations at scientific meetings.
